questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an 'IP core' (Intellectual Property core) in modern System-on-Chip (SoC) design?
options: To perform physical layout verification checks.
To define the instruction set for a custom processor.
To provide pre-designed, reusable functional blocks for integration into a larger chip.
To generate clock signals for different domains on the chip.
To analyze the power consumption of a completed design.

questions.question: In synchronous digital design, what does the 'setup time' of a flip-flop primarily refer to?
options: The minimum time the input data must be held stable *after* the active clock edge.
The maximum time it takes for the clock signal to propagate from its source to the flip-flop.
The minimum time the input data must be stable *before* the active clock edge to be reliably captured.
The maximum delay through the combinational logic feeding the flip-flop.
The time required to reset the flip-flop to its initial state.

questions.question: In a multi-processor system with private caches, what is the primary role of a 'cache coherence protocol'?
options: To determine which block of data to evict when the cache is full.
To translate virtual addresses to physical addresses for cache access.
To ensure that all processors have a consistent view of shared memory, even when data is replicated in multiple caches.
To manage the flow of instructions through a pipeline.
To optimize the power consumption of the cache memory.

questions.question: Which characteristic is a primary advantage of using an Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) over a Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) for high-volume production of a specific digital function?
options: Re-programmability after manufacturing.
Faster time-to-market for initial prototyping.
Lower Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) costs.
Significantly lower unit cost and higher performance/power efficiency.
Greater flexibility for in-field updates and bug fixes.

questions.question: In computer architecture, what is the primary function of general-purpose registers within the CPU?
options: To store the entire operating system kernel.
To provide a small, extremely fast storage area for data and addresses currently being manipulated by the CPU.
To manage the virtual memory mapping for processes.
To store programs on a long-term basis.
To handle input/output operations with peripheral devices.
